It is characterized by its spherical, flower-like structures that resemble small, clustered globes, giving it its scientific name. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments, often in forest understories. Its flowers are usually white or pale pink, and they emit a subtle fragrance. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Sphaerostephanos todayensis is considered a vulnerable species.
